\begin{abstract}
We study static systems of self-gravitating radiations confined in a sphere by using numerical and analytic calculations.

We classify and analyze the solutions systematically.
Due to the scaling symmetry, any solution can be represented as a segment of a solution curve on a plane of two-dimensional scale invariant variables. 
We find that a system can be conveniently parametrized by three parameters representing the solution curve, the scaling, and the system size, instead of the parameters defined at the outer boundary. 
The solution curves are classified to three types representing regular solutions, conically singular solutions with, and without 

an object which resembles an event horizon up to causal disconnectedness.
For the last type, the behavior of a self-gravitating system is simple enough to allow analytic calculations. 
\end{abstract}

\keywords{self-gravitating radiation, gravity, horizon}

\section{Introduction}
A bounded self-gravitating isothermal sphere are an interesting object as a model of a small dense nucleus of stellar systems, which is to some extent independent of the outer parts of the system~\cite{Lynden-Bell}.   

In 1981, a spherically symmetric solution of self-gravitating radiation was presented by Sorkin, Wald, and Jiu~\cite{Sorkin:1981wd} as a solution that maximizing the entropy based on general relativity.
The heat capacity and stability of the solution were further analyzed in Refs.~\cite{Pavon1988} and~\cite{Chavanis:2007kn,Chavanis:2001hd,Chavanis:2001ib}. 
Schmidt and Homann~\cite{Schmidt:1999tr} named the geometry as a `photon star'. 

Thereafter, the system has drawn attentions repeatedly in relation to the entropy bound~\cite{Schiffer:1989et,Hod:1999as}, maximum entropy principle~\cite{Gao:2016trd,Fang:2013oka,Gao:2011hh}, holograpic principle~\cite{Bousso:2002ju,Lemos:2007ys,Anastopoulos:2013xdk}, blackhole thermodynamics~\cite{Sorkin:1997ja}, and excluding blackhole firewalls~\cite{Page:2013mqa}. 

Self-gravitating radiation in Anti-de Sitter spacetime was also pursued~\cite{Page:1985em,Vaganov:2007at,Gentle:2011kv}.
Studies on the systems of self-gravitating perfect fluids are undergoing~\cite{Pesci:2006sb}. 

An interesting extension of the self-gravitating system was presented in Ref.~\cite{Schmidt:1999tr,Anastopoulos:2011av} where a conical singularity was included at the center as an independent mass source from the radiation. 
The singularity was said to be benign in the sense that it does not give rise to inextensible causal geodesics.
Because no timelike geodesics reach the singularity and null geodesics simply pass it.
A thermodynamic interpretation for the conical singularity was also discussed~\cite{Anastopoulos:2011av}.
Some of the singular solutions were shown to have an interesting geometry, which is similar to an event horizon in the sense that $r - 2m(r)$ has a minimum value close to zero.

The solutions can also be used to study a spherical shell of self-gravitating radiations once one places an inner boundary after excising the central part. 

However, we notice that the understanding on the details of the geometry is not satisfactory because its geometric structure is not classified and analyzed throughly. 

The purpose of the present work is to make up for this part.
The key idea of this work is to characterize the spherically symmetric systems in terms of parameters related to the specific properties of system. 
We also show that there are interesting cases which allow analytic analysis rather than numerical techenique.

In this work, we study a spherically symmetric systems of self-gravitating radiation confined in a spherical box of radius $R$ by using numerical calculation and analytic approximations in the context of general relativity.

\section{Summary and discussions}
We studied a system of self-gravitating radiation confined in a spherical box by using numerical and analytic calculations.

We have classified the solution space systematically and then found analytic solutions describing a {\it fake horizon} whose limiting geometry resembles an event horizon.
The behavior of the solutions can be summarized as follows: 
For simplicity, the box is large enough so that its boundary is located in the asymptotic region.
The geometry outside the box is described by the Schwarzschild metric.


Around the center, the mass behaves as $m_{\rm r} \propto r^3$ or $m_{\rm s} \propto -\mu + r^5$ in the absence or in the presence of a central conical singularity, respectively, where $r$ is the areal radial coordinate.
On the other hand, for large $r$, the asymptotic form follows a single formula~$m_a\propto 3r/14$.
In between the two limits, a {\it fake horizon} can appear.
Just outside of a strong {\it fake horizon}, the transient state $m_t \sim 2r_{\rm fh} + \epsilon r^3$ arises for a wide range of $r$, where $\epsilon$ is a very small number.

To classify the solutions, we have designed a set of parameters which describes both of the internal geometry and the boundary data. 

The first parameter $\nu$ identifies a solution curve $C_\nu$ which represents a curve on the two dimensional space  of scale invariant variables $(u,v) \equiv (2m(r)/r, 4\pi r^2 \rho(r))$ which satisfy a first order differential equation between them.

We choose $\nu$ to represent the minimum value of $1-2m(r)/r$ on the curve $C_\nu$.
Therefore, in a sense, it measures how similar a {\it fake horizon} is to an event horizon. 
For $\nu=0$, the {\it fake horizon} is nothing but the event horizon. 
For $0<\nu < \nu_c\approx 0.45269$, the solution has a {\it fake horizon}.
For $\nu_c < \nu< \nu_r \approx 0.50735$, the solution does not have a {\it fake horizon} but has a naked singular origin. 
For $\nu=\nu_r$, the solution is regular.

The second parameter $r_Q$ is the value of the radius at the point that $u$ is maximized. 
It determines the scale of the solution for a given solution curve.
Any point on $C_\nu$ is parameterized by $(u(\xi), v(\xi))$ where $\xi = \log (r/r_Q)$ where $u(\xi)$ and $v(\xi)$ are parameterized functions of $\xi$ determining $C_\nu$.  
The last parameter is the system size $R$.  
Given the three parameters $(\nu, r_Q, R)$, the ADM mass and the surface temperature are given by $M_R=  R u(\xi_R)/2$ and $T= (v(\xi_R)/ 4\pi \sigma R^2)^{1/4}$, respectively, where $\xi_R = \log(R/r_Q)$. 

The merit of this parametrization is that many important physical properties are determined by the position of the boundary on the solution curve.  
For example, if $R> r_Q$, it implies that the box includes the {\it fake horizon} (if it exists).
If $R\approx r_P$, the density there will be very high and the contribution of the radiation to the mass is maximized at the surface.

The sign of the heat capacity for a self-gravitating system~\cite{Pavon1988} is also determined by the position on the solution curve.
In addition, the scale dependence usually takes simple form. 
Especially, the entropy and heat capacity are proportional to $\beta R$.

We have presented a clear definition for the {\it fake horizon} as the set of points other than the origin that (locally) minimizes $\chi\equiv (r-2m(r))/2M$ for the spherically symmetric geometry, where $M$ is an arbitrary positive mass scale.    
From the point of view of outside observers, the geometry around a {\it fake horizon} resembles an event horizon except for a crucial requirement, the causal disconnectedness.  
We proved that the {\it fake horizon} is absent or unique for a given solution curve.
 
The geometry around a strong {\it fake horizon} is shown to be described analytically.
An interesting point is that the heat capacity for systems having boundary around the {\it fake horizon} is positive definite even with the geometrical similarity to the event horizon. 

Both the geometry and energy density change drastically just inside the {\it fake horizon} but a wide approximately constant mass region appears outside of it with the form of $m_t$.
The geometry here resembles that of the Schwarzschild blackhole.
Systems having boundary in this region has negative heat capacity. 
The stability~\cite{Chavanis:2001hd,Chavanis:2001ib} issues remain in relation to the negativity of the heat capacity. 


It is interesting to ask the origin of a {\it fake horizon}. 
In the presence of ordinary matters, the pressure (and density due to equation of state) is higher for smaller $r$ because the gravity is attractive. 
The regular solutions shows exactly the behavior where the density decreases monotonically with $r$. 
On the other hand, for a system having a conical singularity, the density of the radiation vanishes at the center and increases with $r$ around the center ($\rho_s \propto r^2$). 

In fact, the central conical singularity plays the role of a negative mass which repels every (positive mass) things including the radiations. 
Therefore, $\chi$ takes a positive value at the origin.
As can be seen from the Newtonian gravity formula, $F\propto r^{-2}$, the repulsive force will decrease with $r$.

On the other hand, the gravity of radiations must be attractive. 
Therefore, the radiations try to be gathered around the center. 
Eventually, the radiations will be stacked up around a certain radius where the repulsive force of the negative mass is balanced with the gravitational attraction of the radiation.
Specifically, $2M d\chi/dr = 1-8\pi r^2\rho(r)$ is positive at the origin. 
However, it soon becomes negative for $r> r_c$ satisfying $\rho(r_c)\sim 1/8\pi r_c^2$ if the density increases with $r$, which really happens around the center.
In the asymptotic region without matters, we have $d\chi/dr =1$. 
This implies that there exist local minima of $\chi$ at $r> r_c$, which is a {\it fake horizon}. 
On the whole, we notice that a {\it fake horizon} exists when the central negative mass is large so that $\nu< \nu_c$ and the size of the box is larger than $r_{\rm fh} \sim r_Q$.
